Derek,

You wrote:
> But certainly you don't mean to say that natural selec=
tion (and other evolutionary pressures) still aren't acting upon millions o=
f species worldwide every day?

By heavens, NO!  I was attempting to distin=
guish homo-sapien's influencing it.  For example, we are far from sufficien=
tly "controlling" it at the bacterial and viral levels.  The recent outbrea=
k of SARS is evidence we still largely react to evolution even now.

As you=
 point out, we have been influencing it for quite some time within specific=
 species.


Jim


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Derek James 
  To=
: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, January 29, 2004 1:18 PM
  Subjec=
t: [neat] Re: Definition of Evolution


  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jim=
 O'Flaherty, Jr." 
  <jim_oflaherty_jr@y...> wrote:
  > As for my disagreem=
ent - Evolution may remain an unintended 
  > process  I feel this just des=
cribes
  > its origins.  However, I do not think it can be said accurately =
it 
  > remains undirected.

  Well as long as there has been agriculture a=
nd domestication of 
  plants and animals there has been directed evolution=
.  The particular 
  selection pressure applied by humans to isolated popul=
ations has a 
  name: Artificial Selection.  It's how we got poodles and fl=
ower shops.

  But certainly you don't mean to say that natural selection (=
and other 
  evolutionary pressures) still aren't acting upon millions of s=
pecies 
  worldwide every day?

  Derek
